snippet: The national debate on measles and immunization poses a challenge for Republican presidential hopefuls, who must reconcile modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.
abstract: Measles outbreak has presented quandary for Republican contenders in 2016 presidential election as they seek to balance personal choice and public health in debate over vaccinations; candidates find themselves in familiar if uncomfortable position of reconciling demands of modern science with skepticism of their base.

byline.original: By JEREMY W. PETERS and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
byline.contributor: Jeremy W. Peters reported from Washington, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Nick Corasaniti contributed reporting from Washington, and Kitty Bennett from St. Petersburg, Fla.

lead_paragraph: The national debate on measles and immunization poses a challenge for Republican presidential hopefuls, who must reconcile modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.

headline.main: Measles Outbreak Proves Delicate Issue to G.O.P. Field
headline.print_headline: Measles Proves Delicate Issue to G.O.P. Field
